replies.bodyText: I use the totalCopyJob request number to make a determination about what the thread pool size should be in the determineThreadPoolSize method. I figured since we use it twice it could be worth throwing into a variable.
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

replies.bodyText: Ah, OK, I didn't spot that, sorry, you're right.
replies.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Why has all this been moved down here instead of where it was being done above?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: OK, so that's why you had to move it down here then.
replies.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText:
So the thought behind this was that we don't initialize the target & transferManager until we know how much work we need to do and we can optimize how we allocate those threads dynamically. The number of threads we allocate to the threadpool has a diminishing return if we go over the total number of copies we need to make.
I.e. if we have 250 copy jobs and we allocate a threadpool of 1000 to transfermanager, we're going to have ~750 idle threads. This made a fairly significant difference in overhead and the total replication time from our testing of about an average of ~400 MB/s (granted the # of files & size of those files will drastically change that number)
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

replies.bodyText: OK.
replies.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: I've got a feeling this was set to debug for a reason, why is it being changed to warn?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: The reason I say this is because we usually log errors on warn/error level so if we don't then it's usually been done like that for a reason. My assumption is that we have some retry logic so this was causing the logs to be noisy and was downgraded to debug but I could be wrong, in which case warn is fine.
replies.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: I changed this because during my testing of all of this since some of the failures we had around the testing of this made those errors fail silently. If we're running in production, we don't necessarily want to have debug logs on but we still want to see what the failure for a given job was.
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

replies.bodyText: OK, well, let's leave it like this then and if it later becomes apparent why we put this down to debug we'll just just put it back again.
replies.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: I don't really mind but why was this removed?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: unintentional - I had a ton of additional debug logs that I had reverted for the PR, and this one must have gotten caught with it.
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

timeline.author: massdosage
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,41 @@
+package com.hotels.bdp.circustrain.s3s3copier.aws;

timeline.bodyText: Can we add a unit test for this if statement or is it not straightforward to check the existence of the executor factory?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: I had originally added the transfermanagerFactoryTest to cover it but found that it wasn't straightforward. That property is directly set on the executor factory which transferManager stores under a private final w/o any getters.
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need this here as well as in the TransferManagerFactory?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText:
The call in TransferManagerFactory sets the max threads that are available for its pool but doesn't update the default connection limit that the S3Client has of 50. So if you were to set a thread pool of 100, you'd start hitting connection failures.
From my research into it, the most efficient scenario is to match # of threads to # of available connections.
replies.author: KenFigueiredo

replies.bodyText: OK
replies.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Can we just have a simple test class for this?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: good catch - this is actually completely unused and unneeded now due to it being replaced by the lambda call. Removed.
